title: 109_s254
content: The Act titled as the "Central Nevada Rural Cemeteries Act" conveys land to Lander County, Nevada. Congress finds that the historical use of Kingston Cemetery predates Forest Service jurisdiction, and it is appropriate for local public ownership. The Forest Service has conveyed 1.25 acres to the Town of Kingston under the Townsite Act to preserve historic gravesites. The Forest Service will convey approximately 8.75 acres to Lander County for the Kingston Cemetery to ensure future gravesite availability. The conveyance is subject to conditions and must be completed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The parcel of National Forest System land known as "Kingston Cemetery" consisting of approximately 10 acres will be conveyed to Lander County. The county must use the land as a cemetery, and an easement will be granted for access to the cemetery. The Secretary may revoke title to the parcel and easement if the county uses the land for any purpose other than as a cemetery. The Secretary has the authority to waive this if it benefits the United States. The Secretary has the authority to waive this if it benefits the United States. Conveyance to Eureka County, Nevada. Congress finds that the historical use of the cemetery known as "Maiden's Grave Cemetery" predates incorporation of the land within the jurisdiction of the Bureau of Land Management. It is deemed appropriate for the local public ownership of the parcel rather than through the permitting process of the Federal agency. The Secretary of the Interior shall convey the cemetery to Eureka County, Nevada, subject to certain conditions. The United States conveys the Maiden's Grave Cemetery, a 10-acre parcel of public land, to Eureka County, Nevada. The Secretary grants the county an easement for cemetery access. The county must adhere to conditions for land use. The county must use the conveyed parcel as a cemetery. If the county uses the parcel for any other purpose, title reverts to the Secretary and the easement is revoked, unless waived by the Secretary in the best interests of the United States. The Secretary may waive the easement if it is in the best interests of the United States.
